title: 114_s1550
content: The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies under the Deputy Director for Management. The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" mandates the Deputy Director for Management to oversee program and project management standards, policies, and guidelines in executive agencies. This includes chairing the Program Management Policy Council, establishing standards and policies, engaging with the private sector for best practices, and conducting portfolio reviews. The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" requires the Deputy Director for Management to oversee program and project management standards in executive agencies. This involves conducting portfolio reviews, coordinating with Project Management Improvement Officers, and establishing a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are similar or duplicative. The Deputy Director for Management must issue standards, policies, and guidelines within a year of the Act's enactment. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are similar or duplicative. The Deputy Director for Management, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, will issue regulations within 90 days to implement section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Program Management Improvement Officers and the Program Management Policy Council are also established. The Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council are established under Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code. Each agency must designate a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer, who will have specific functions within the agency. The agency designated under paragraph (1) must implement program management policies and develop a strategy to enhance the role of program managers, including providing enhanced training and educational opportunities. The agency must provide training for program and project managers in the private sector, focusing on relevant competencies and cost containment for large projects and programs. The agency aims to improve program management by mentoring current and future managers, enhancing career paths, recruiting qualified individuals, sharing best practices, and providing common tools and templates. The subsection provides common templates and tools for data gathering and analysis in program management. It does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions exist in chapter 87 of title 10. The Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics is designated as the Program Management Improvement Officer. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the main interagency forum for enhancing agency practices in program and project management. It advises the Deputy Director for Management and reviews high-risk programs identified by the General Accountability Office, making recommendations. The Program Management Policy Council advises the Deputy Director for Management on workforce development, program management improvement, and challenges in managing programs. It also recommends actions for high-risk programs identified by the General Accountability Office. The Program Management Policy Council sets governmentwide standards for program management transparency and reviews information on the Office of Management and Budget's website. Membership includes five members from the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council, consisting of five members from the Office of Management and Budget, includes key positions such as the Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management. The Program Management Policy Council includes the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget as the Chairperson, with a Vice Chairperson elected by the members for a term of up to 1 year. Other members include agency Program Management Improvement Officers and designated federal government employees or Armed Forces members. The Chairperson of the Program Management Policy Council is elected by the members and serves a term of up to 1 year. Their duties include presiding over meetings, determining the agenda, directing the work, and establishing subgroups. The Council must meet at least twice per fiscal year and can meet at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members. Agency heads with a Project Management Improvement Officer on the Council must provide support. The Management Improvement Officer supports the Council as requested by the Chairperson. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress within a year, detailing the strategy developed by Program Management Improvement Officers. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 180 days to identify key skills and competencies needed for agency personnel standards. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 180 days to identify key skills and competencies needed for a program and project manager in an agency, establish a new job series or update an existing one, and create a new career path for program and project managers within an agency. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies on program and project management within 3 years of the enactment of this Act. The report evaluates the effectiveness of standards, policies, guidelines, the 5-year strategic plan, Program Management Improvement Officers, and the Program Management Policy Council on improving Federal program and project management. The report assesses the impact of standards, policies, guidelines, strategic plan, Program Management Improvement Officers, and Program Management Policy Council on enhancing Federal program and project management, including section 1126(b)(1) of title 31, United States Code.
